mn150:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Nagaravinda.
mn150:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda heard,
mn150:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Nagaravinda, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
mn150:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn150:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
mn150:2.6: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
mn150:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
mn150:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:
mn150:4.1: “Householders, if wanderers who follow another path were to ask you:
mn150:4.2: ‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin doesn’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’
mn150:4.4: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:4.6: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us.
mn150:4.7: That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:4.8: There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear …
mn150:4.12: thoughts known by the mind, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:4.14: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us.
mn150:4.15: That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.’
mn150:4.16: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.
mn150:5.1: If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you:
mn150:5.2: ‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin deserves honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’
mn150:5.4: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:5.6: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us.
mn150:5.7: That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:5.8: There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear …
mn150:5.12: thoughts known by the mind, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:5.14: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us.
mn150:5.15: That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
mn150:5.16: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.
mn150:6.1: If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you:
mn150:6.2: ‘But what reasons and evidence do you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying,
mn150:6.3: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’
mn150:6.5: ‘It’s because those venerables frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
mn150:6.6: In such places there are no sights known by the eye to see and enjoy, there are no sounds known by the ear to hear and enjoy, no odors known by the nose to smell and enjoy, no flavors known by the tongue to taste and enjoy, and no touches known by the body to feel and enjoy.
mn150:6.7: These are the reasons and evidence that you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying,
mn150:6.8: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”.’
mn150:6.9: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.”
mn150:7.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda said to the Buddha,
mn150:7.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
mn150:7.4: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn150:7.5: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
